body:
Thanks for the pull request, and welcome! The Rust team is excited to review your changes, and you should hear from @steveklabnik (or someone else) soon.

If any changes to this PR are deemed necessary, please add them as extra commits. This ensures that the reviewer can see what has changed since they last reviewed the code. The way Github handles out-of-date commits, this should also make it reasonably obvious what issues have or haven't been addressed. Large or tricky changes may require several passes of review and changes.

Please see [the contribution instructions](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) for more information.
Beat me to it! Part of what was taking me so long was fixing the doc tests. It _looks_ like a lot of yours will fail if you run `rustdoc --test` on it (which I assume is part of the build process).
Oh.
Hmm. Yeah. 41 fail. That's strange.

@christopherdumas It's because of the way I setup the code. The code is itself defined in the article, but it is [extracted and stitched together](https://github.com/BurntSushi/blog/blob/master/scripts/rust-from-blog) to [generate full Rust programs](https://github.com/BurntSushi/blog/tree/master/code/rust-error-handling/src/bin), which collectively form a Cargo package. This alleviated me from having a bunch of `# fn some_func_defined_earlier_but_used_again() { ... }` everywhere. I was adding those in, but it looks like the task has fallen to you. :-)
@christopherdumas And you'll probably have to `ignore` a lot of the tests at the end in the case study since they use external crates.

Okay, so this is relevant, but this is why I said it shouldn't take too much editing: https://users.rust-lang.org/t/the-rust-programming-language-is-going-to-be-published-by-no-starch-press/2777

TL;DR: we're gonna get the book published, so I will have a Real Editor reading over it at some point, so we can take care of any problems then. :confetti_ball:
Ok. But I'll still be looking at it to see if theres an easier way to get the tests to run.
Whew! @christopherdumas , I left some things. I'm willing to chip in too, this is the drudge work involved in long-form docs :)
@christopherdumas Let me know if you want me to take over fixing the tests. I think I made it 25% of the way through. I'd submit a PR to your fork?
Sure, @BurntSushi. OK thanks @steveklabnik.
You can submit a PR, @BurntSushi, but I was kind of exited to stretch my Perl/sed/Awk skills a little and see what happens.
Heh, OK, I'll finish up my fixes and submit a PR to you. This is definitely not a job for perl/sed/awk. :-)
Yeah, on second thought, maybe not. But in any case, I don't mind repetitive tasks.
@christopherdumas I have it done. Hopefully PR incoming soon...
@christopherdumas Could you merge master into your branch please?
My forks master or rust master?
I'm away from home right now, so it might be a while. Sorry.
Rust master (since that's what I based my changes on).
No worries!
@BurntSushi ok I've merged with master.
@steveklabnik I'll make those changes you suggested on the diff.
@BurntSushi, @steveklabnik whats the consensus on wether or not we should remove the case study?

@christopherdumas Would you be willing to change the case study to use `getopts` instead of `docopt`? I think it might actually require some small structural changes to the case study since the prose does mention `docopt` and adding new arguments to the CLI. So it's definitely not a trivial change... Otherwise, I guess we either have to remove it, or play favorite with `docopt` temporarily.
Im totally willing to change it to use getopts.

@BurntSushi The link to your github repo seems out of place to me, and the repo will end up being different then the case study because it will use docopt, whereas the case study will use getopts. Should I delete that part?
Yup, absolutely!
@steveklabnik Do you have any idea why travis fails?
Yeah check out https://s3.amazonaws.com/archive.travis-ci.org/jobs/79476198/log.txt , a few pages up from the bottom. There are a lot of "use of undeclared type or module" errors.
Thanks @steveklabnik! I did look at the logs, but I think I missed that. By the way, I'm done doing the edits you wanted, and I've finished the rewrite of the case study.
:confetti_ball:
I'm now working on finding all the errors and fixing them, so travis will stop failing. It should take about 2 hours at the max.
How do I get the rust tests to ignore certain blocks of code?

``````
```no_run
``````

compiles and doesn't run

``````
```ignore
``````

ignores entirely.
It seems like adding all the previous code to every code example is needlessly annoying for both reader and writer. I would hate to read a book like that. Perhaps I should add `no_run` to everything?
@christopherdumas Uh... No... Please don't add `no_run`. Could you please [merge my PR to your branch instead](https://github.com/christopherdumas/rust/pull/2)? It should fix all the doctests.
@christopherdumas The case study rewrite looks great! Thanks for doing that!
@BurntSushi  Thanks! The tests are passing now.

:confetti_ball: 

I'll re-review again
This is still using straight `"` and `'` instead of the curly ones.
getting close!!!!!
yeah! @steveklabnik sorry about all the little things that i missed.
@steveklabnik Do you really want to use curly quotes in code blocks? Seems strange to me...

Not in code blocks, but in the prose.

(and no worries about missing things, that's exactly why we review! I do it
all the time)
OK, I've added curly quotes.

Okay! I think this is good to go. We just need
1. the llvm change still needs to go
2. squash it down

r=me afterwards!
@steveklabnik What does `r=me` mean?

@christopherdumas For squashing, I think you want to rebase your branch against master. Usually what I do is  (with your branch checked out and `master` up to date) `git rebase -i master`. Then squash all the commits into one. Then it should give you an opportunity to rewrite the commit message for one commit with all your changes.
@BurntSushi I tried to do this, but it couldn't apply one of the commits, (the one with the merge conflict). Any advice?
OK, I squashed all of the commits!
@BurntSushi @steveklabnik Were ready to merge this!
:confetti_ball:
@bors r=@steveklabnik
@BurntSushi is this command correct? `@bors=@steveklabnik`
@christopherdumas Incidentally, I am not well versed in the language of bors. Best to wait for @steveklabnik to come and get it squared away. :-)
Is there a manual for bors? It seems like having one would be a good idea.
I think my command was correct, but because I'm not a collaborator or an owner, bors ignored me.
@christopherdumas Well, only people with access can wield the power of bors.
Can you try my command? You have access...
@bors r=steveklabnik

:pushpin: Commit e181226 has been approved by `steveklabnik`

<!-- @bors r=steveklabnik e18122682b649a9bff8cbc7b7a4bc8e1f753fb30 -->

@bors: r+

> On Sep 10, 2015, at 12:49, Christopher Dumas notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> @BurntSushi @steveklabnik Were ready to merge this!
> 
> ―
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

:pushpin: Commit e181226 has been approved by `steveklabnik`

<!-- @bors r=steveklabnik e18122682b649a9bff8cbc7b7a4bc8e1f753fb30 -->

Yup! Bors only listens to people who have permissions. It's useful because if another committer came along, they could authorize it on my behalf.

> On Sep 10, 2015, at 12:49, Christopher Dumas notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> @BurntSushi @steveklabnik Were ready to merge this!
> 
> ―
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
@steveklabnik is there a manual for bors yet?
:hourglass: Testing commit e181226 with merge 98eeded...

:sunny: Test successful - [auto-linux-32-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-32-nopt-t/builds/6385), [auto-linux-32-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-32-opt/builds/6399), [auto-linux-64-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-64-nopt-t/builds/6338), [auto-linux-64-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-64-opt/builds/6364), [auto-linux-64-x-android-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-64-x-android-t/builds/6342), [auto-mac-32-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-mac-32-opt/builds/6418), [auto-mac-64-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-mac-64-nopt-t/builds/6412), [auto-mac-64-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-mac-64-opt/builds/6376), [auto-win-gnu-32-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-gnu-32-nopt-t/builds/1359), [auto-win-gnu-32-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-gnu-32-opt/builds/1358), [auto-win-gnu-64-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-gnu-64-nopt-t/builds/1360), [auto-win-gnu-64-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-gnu-64-opt/builds/1362), [auto-win-msvc-32-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-msvc-32-opt/builds/640), [auto-win-msvc-64-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-msvc-64-opt/builds/1341)
:tada: Nice work @christopherdumas! :D
Thanks! And thank you for the help, and the great blog post!
